pull.title: Always enforce strict lock ordering (try or not)
pull.body: We're pretty close to using consistent lock ordering even within try locks, it seems. This is a simple fixup to match the lockorders used elsewhere.

repo.name: bitcoin
repo.description: Bitcoin (dont fork from here, fork from bitcoin/bitcoin)

events.message: Lock cs_vSend and cs_inventory in a consistent order even in TRY

events.body: Does it even matter if TRYLOCK ordering is consistent?
@pstratem if the ordering is inconsistent,  you could have a situation where two threads have both locked their respective first lock,  and unable to gain the second.
@dcousens yeah but they're try locks, so they'll fail and try again and one will eventually succeed

@pstratem in that situation,  wouldn't they both succeed on the first, and continually try again on the second [if the ordering was inconsistent]?

I suppose you're right, it would get through eventually,  but,  it does seem better to avoid that if possible no?
A thread doing (L1, try L2) and another doing (L2, L1) is not a problem. A thread doing (try L1, L2) and another doing (L2, L1) is a problem.

events.message: Always enforce lock strict lock ordering (try or not)

events.body:
No, in this case it does not matter, but for code hygene we should generally try to (and it can matter, as @sipa points out).

Turns out that, at least for our travis test cases, this lock inversion was the only one left, so DEBUG_LOCKORDER now enforces for all lock inversions.

rename.from: Lock cs_vSend and cs_inventory in a consistent order even in TRY
rename.to: Always enforce strict lock ordering (try or not)

events.body: Well it simplifies the checking code at least that's a good thing...

The checking code is now also able to detect some deadlocks that it previously was unable to, though I'd have to go stare at it for a while to recall which those were.

On February 3, 2017 3:09:43 AM EST, "Wladimir J. van der Laan" <notifications@github.com> wrote:
>Well it simplifies the checking code at least that's a good thing...
>

events.message: Fixup style a bit by moving { to the same line as if statements

events.body: Pushed a commit that purely does style fixes (moves { up to the same line as if). Would like to see the agressive DEBUG_LOCKORDER assertions in 0.14rc1 for testers, but its not the end of the world to miss.
I think this should go in 0.14. utACK.

events.message: Further-enforce lockordering by enforcing directly after TRY_LOCKs

events.body:
> Would like to see the agressive DEBUG_LOCKORDER assertions in 0.14rc1 for testers

Note that we don't build releases (and neither release candidates) with DEBUG_LOCKORDER enabled.

I'm aware, but I hope some testers do, if only other devs.

issue.title: Remove unused fTry from push_lock
issue.body: After #9674 (618ee92) the `fTry` argument in `push_lock` is no longer needed.

issue.title: Disallow messages before receiving VERACK
issue.body:
* fd13eca from https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9674
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9715 - Disconnect peers which we do not receive VERACKs from within 60 sec
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9720 - net: fix banning and disallow sending messages before receiving verack
    * c45b9f - I already wrote the same function as SendRejectsAndCheckIfBanned. Moved it to utilprocessmsg instead of moving it up in main.
    * skipped 5b5e4f8 and 8650bbb, we already got them in 9715

issue.title: [Core] Lock cs_vSend and cs_inventory in a consistent order even in TRY
issue.body:
Fixes another inconsistency found with #1920 :
```
2020-10-15 23:43:11 POTENTIAL DEADLOCK DETECTED
2020-10-15 23:43:11 Previous lock order was:
2020-10-15 23:43:11  (1) pnode->cs_vSend net.cpp:1152 (TRY) (in thread pivx-net)
2020-10-15 23:43:11  (2) pnode->cs_inventory net.cpp:1154 (TRY) (in thread pivx-net)
2020-10-15 23:43:11 Current lock order is:
2020-10-15 23:43:11  pnode->cs_sendProcessing net.cpp:1898 (in thread pivx-msghand)
2020-10-15 23:43:11  cs_main net_processing.cpp:1992 (TRY) (in thread pivx-msghand)
2020-10-15 23:43:11  (2) pto->cs_inventory net_processing.cpp:2081 (in thread pivx-msghand)
2020-10-15 23:43:11  (1) pnode->cs_vSend net.cpp:2568 (in thread pivx-msghand)
```

backporting the only missing commit from upstream bitcoin/bitcoin#9674

issue.title: Sync backports
issue.body:
Cherry-picked from the following upstream PRs:
- bitcoin/bitcoin#8392
  - We cherry-picked the second commit in zcash/zcash#2812.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9535
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9674
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9987
  - Excluding code that is still in use for us.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#11432
- bitcoin/bitcoin#10866
  - Excluding the third commit (we don't have the code it alters).
- bitcoin/bitcoin#11722
- bitcoin/bitcoin#12283
  - Only the typos we currently have.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#12367
  - Only the first commit, which fixes a bug in bitcoin/bitcoin#8392.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#12891
  - Only the first commit (the linter is useless for our logging system).
- bitcoin/bitcoin#13236
- bitcoin/bitcoin#13300
- bitcoin/bitcoin#13423
  - Only the first commit (second commit blocks on net processing refactors).
- bitcoin/bitcoin#11640
- bitcoin/bitcoin#11599
- bitcoin/bitcoin#14963
  - Only the first and third commits.

issue.title: Mutex lock failure results in crash on exit on native macOS or in debug mode
issue.body:
Latest master.

Reproducibility: always

Introduced in the latest commits.

```
Process 53528 launched: '/Users/rex/zcash/src/zcashd' (x86_64)

% zcash-cli stop

libc++abi: terminating with uncaught exception of type boost::wrapexcept<boost::lock_error>: boost: mutex lock failed in pthread_mutex_lock: Invalid argument
Process 53528 stopped
* thread #1, name = 'zcash-shutoff', queue = 'com.apple.main-thread', stop reason = breakpoint 10.4
    frame #0: 0x00007fff20671399 libsystem_c.dylib`abort
libsystem_c.dylib`abort:
->  0x7fff20671399 <+0>: pushq  %rbp
    0x7fff2067139a <+1>: movq   %rsp, %rbp
    0x7fff2067139d <+4>: pushq  %r14
    0x7fff2067139f <+6>: pushq  %rbx
Target 0: (zcashd) stopped.
(lldb) bt
* thread #1, name = 'zcash-shutoff', queue = 'com.apple.main-thread', stop reason = breakpoint 10.4
  * frame #0: 0x00007fff20671399 libsystem_c.dylib`abort
    frame #1: 0x00007fff206dfef2 libc++abi.dylib`abort_message + 241
    frame #2: 0x00007fff206d15e5 libc++abi.dylib`demangling_terminate_handler() + 242
    frame #3: 0x00007fff205ca595 libobjc.A.dylib`_objc_terminate() + 104
    frame #4: 0x00007fff206df307 libc++abi.dylib`std::__terminate(void (*)()) + 8
    frame #5: 0x00007fff206df2a9 libc++abi.dylib`std::terminate() + 41
    frame #6: 0x00000001000030af zcashd`__clang_call_terminate + 15
    frame #7: 0x0000000100410b47 zcashd`CNetCleanup::~CNetCleanup(this=0x0000000101629470) at net.cpp:2014:13
    frame #8: 0x00000001003c82f3 zcashd`CNetCleanup::~CNetCleanup(this=0x0000000101629470) at net.cpp:2011:5
    frame #9: 0x00007fff2064bd35 libsystem_c.dylib`__cxa_finalize_ranges + 316
    frame #10: 0x00007fff2064c020 libsystem_c.dylib`exit + 53
    frame #11: 0x00007fff20737f44 libdyld.dylib`start + 8
```

comments.body:
Do you need to get rid of the if (!fTry) condition below in push_lock() to make this happen with trylocks?

Also, it doesn't appear to that invlockorders variable is ever used here. Can it be deleted?
Never mind about invlockorders, seems to be needed to clean up lockorders when the lock is deleted.
